<script>
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
setTimeout(function() {
    var clozeBoxes = document.querySelector(".cloze cloze2_w");
    var elements = document.querySelectorAll("cloze2." + clozeBoxes.className);
    for(var i = 0 ; i < elements.length ; i++) {
        elements[i].style.display="inline";
    }
}, 0);
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
</script>


<script>
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
setTimeout(function() {
    var clozeBoxes = document.querySelector(".cloze cloze2_w");
    var elements = document.querySelectorAll("cloze2." + clozeBoxes.className);
    for(var i = 0 ; i < elements.length ; i++) {
        elements[i].classList.add("cloze");
        elements[i].style.display="inline";
    }
}, 0);
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
</script>



{{cloze:Text}}
{{#Extra}}
<hr>
{{Extra}}
{{/Extra}}

{{#Hide others on the back side}}
<style>
cloze2 {
    display: none;
}

cloze2_w {
    display: inline-block;
    width: 5em;
    height: 1em;
    background-color: #ffeba2;
}

.cloze cloze2 {
    display: inline;
}

.cloze cloze2_w {
    display: none;
}

cloze2.reveal-cloze2 {
    display: inline;
}

cloze2_w.reveal-cloze2 {
    display: none;
}

.cloze2-toggle {
    -webkit-appearance: none;
    display: block;
    font-size: 1.3em;
    height: 2em;
    background-color: #ffffff;
    width: 100%;
    margin-top: 20px;
}

.cloze2-toggle:active {
    background-color: #ffffaa;
}
</style>

<script>
function toggle() {
var elements = document.querySelectorAll('cloze2, cloze2_w');
    for(var i = 0 ; i < elements.length ; i++) {
        elements[i].classList.toggle('reveal-cloze2');
    }
}
</script>



<button class='cloze2-toggle' onclick='toggle()'>Toogle mask</button>
{{/Hide others on the back side}}

<script>
var createCookie = function(name, value, days) {
    var expires;
    if (days) {
        var date = new Date();
        date.setTime(date.getTime() + (days * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000));
        expires = "; expires=" + date.toGMTString();
    }
    else {
        expires = "";
    }
    document.cookie = name + "=" + value + expires + "; path=/";
}
function getCookie(c_name) {
    if (document.cookie.length > 0) {
        c_start = document.cookie.indexOf(c_name + "=");
        if (c_start != -1) {
            c_start = c_start + c_name.length + 1;
            c_end = document.cookie.indexOf(";", c_start);
            if (c_end == -1) {
                c_end = document.cookie.length;
            }
            return unescape(document.cookie.substring(c_start, c_end));
        }
    }
    return "";
}
function getRandomElms(){
    var ul = document.querySelectorAll('ul.shuffle');
    return ul
}
function getRandArr(elm, array){
    for (var i = elm.children.length; i >= 0; i--) {
        rand = Math.random() * i | 0;
        array.push(rand)
    }
}
function shuffleWithArr(elm, array){
    elm.style.backgroundColor = "inherit"
    for (var i = elm.children.length; i >= 0; i--) {
        elm.appendChild(elm.children[array[i]]);
    }
}
function run() {
    var elms = getRandomElms()
    var isFront = document.getElementById("front");
    for (var i = 0; i < elms.length; i++) {
        var idxArr = [];
        elm = elms[i]
        if (isFront) {
            getRandArr(elm, idxArr);
            // convert idxArr array to a JSON string to be stored
            var json_str = JSON.stringify(idxArr);
            // persist the idxArr order and correct answers
            createCookie('idxArr' + i, json_str);
            var stored_data = idxArr
        } else {
            // get the idxArr order
            var json_data = getCookie('idxArr' + i);
            // get the array back from storage
            var stored_data = JSON.parse(json_data);
        }
        shuffleWithArr(elm, stored_data)
    }
}
run();
</script>

fields: 2 purposes of the Nucleic Acid Test (NAT) or Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT)

1. detect and amplify nucleic acid of the pathogen

2. shorten the window period (time between infection and positive results)
What are susceptibility tests used for?
As a guide in choosing antimicrobial therapy since some microbes show unpredictable sensitivity patterns to various antibiotics
What is the Kirby Bauer Disk Diffusion Method?

Tests organisms resistance to a drug by placing exact amounts of different antimicrobial agents on a culture disc inoculated with the microbe to be tested. Then after 24-48 hours, you see how large the zone of inhibition is. 

Larger zone of inhibition = more sensitive the microbe is to the drug
Explain the Minimal Inhibitory Concentration test...
A dilution technique where different concentrations of an antibiotic are used to find the minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) that inhibits bacterial growth.
Bacteriostatics VS Bactericidal Drug Graph
Agents that kill bacteria are...
bactericidals
Drugs that arrest growth and replication of bacteria are...
bacteriostatics
An antibiotic can be (____) for one organism and (____) for another organism.

bacteriostatic

bactericidal
Microbiology labs are increasingly using {{c1::automated}} methods to identify bacterial pathogens.
Example of automated systems biochemical identification (2)

1) Vitek test card containing test wells
2) Color of well changes with time
What do immunologic methods take advantage of in detection of microorganisms?
specifity of antigen-antibody binding
When is it useful to use immunologic methods for detecting microorganisms? (2)

1) infecting microorganism is difficult or impossible to isolate
2) previous infection needs to be documented
Most methods for determining whether antibodies or antigens are present in a patients' sera or other body fluid require a type of {{c1::immunoassay}} procedure.
What do immunologic detection methods look for? (2)

1) detection of microbial antigen with known antiserum (antibodies)
2) detection of serum antibodies
What are the 6 immunologic detection methods?

1. Quellung Reaction
2. Agglutination tests
3. Complement fixation tests
4. ELISA tests
5. Western blotting
6. Fluorescent Antibody Test
How does the Quellung Reaction detect microorganisms?

Makes bacteria with capsule more visible (appears swollen) when organisms are treated with serum that contains specific antibodies.

capsule does not actually swell
Quellung = swelling in German
How does the Latex Agglutination Test detect microorganisms?

- latex and other particles can be coated with antibody (for antigen detection) or antigen (for antibody detection)
- addition of antigen to antibody coated latex beads causes agglutination that can be visibly observed
How does complement fixation detect microorganisms?

- detects patients serum antibody, directed against a specific pathogen by the ability of the antibody to bind complement.
- solution turns pink if negative
- initially, serum is heated to destroy patients' natural complemenet but not their antibody.
5 Steps of Complement Fixation

1. serum is heated to destroy patients' natural complement but not their antibody
2. fixed amount of antigen is added to test serum (if antibody is present, immune complexes will form)
3. complement is added to mixture and will fix and sequester complexes if they are present.
4. RBCs and subagglutinating amounts of anti-erythrocyte antibody are added.
5. If complement has not been bound anti-erythrocyte antibody plus complement will lyse the RBCs to make liquid pink (negative result)
    If complement was bound by the immune complexes, RBCs will not lyse. (positive result)
What does ELISA stand for?
Enzyme Linked ImmunoSorbent Assay
How does ELISA detect microorganisms?

- in the assay, antigen of interest is immobilized by direct adsorption to the assay plate or by first attaching a capture antibody to the plate surface.
- antigen is detected by using an enzyme conjugated primary antibody (direct detection)
   or a matched set of unlabeled primary and conjugated secondary antibodies (indirect detection)
- read in a microplate reader


Ag: Unknown Antigen
E: Enzyme (converts substrate into a colored product)
In ELISA detection what are the advantages and disadvantages of Direct Detection?

advantage: only one antibody is needed and it requires less time to complete assay.
disadvantage: less flexibility in choice of enzyme-substrate detection system, and a labeled antibody must be created for each ELISA experiment
In ELISA detection what are the advantages and disadvantages of Indirect Detection?

advantage:  flexibility and choice availability of secondary antibodies and enzyme-substrate detection systems.

disadvantage: the potential for non-specific cross-reactivity of the secondary antibody.
In ELISA detection what are the advantages and disadvantages of Capture Assay?

advantage: High sensitivity; 2-5 times more sensitive than direct or indirect ELISA

disadvantage: cross reactivity may occur between the capture and detection antibodies
How does Western Blotting detect microorganisms?
similarly to ELISA except more specific as gel electrophoresis protein separation is initially performed.
Outline the 6 steps in Western Blotting
The SDS page in western blotting gel electrophoresis makes protein {{c1::negative}}
Steps in Fluorescent Antibody Tests (2)

1) add fluorescent labeled antiviral antibodies to microscope slide with tissue or cells
2) view with a fluorescent microscope
The success of culturing depends on appropriate collection and transport techniques and on the selection of appropriate {{c1::culture media }}, because some organisms require specific nutrients.
All clinically important bacteria are {{c1::heterotrophs}}, meaning they require organic carbon for growth.
Organisms that require either a large number of growth factors or must be supplied with very specific ones are reffered to as {{c1::fastidious.}}
{{c1::obligate aerobes}} {{c2::require oxygen for growth }}
{{c1::Obligate anaerobes}} {{c2::require anaerobic enviornment for growth. }}
{{c1::Facultative anaerobes}} {{c2::have the ability to grow anaerobically, but grow better with O2}}
{{c1::Aerotolerant Anaerobes}} {{c2::do not use oxygen for growth but can tolerate it.}}
{{c1::Microaerophiles}} {{c2::require oxygen concentrations lower than O2 found in the air }}
Solid Medium (also known as {{c1::nutirent agar}}) is used for {{c1::isolating bacterium}}
Liquid Medium (also known as {{c1::nutrient broth}}) is used to {{c2::grow larger quantitiies of a bacterium that have already been isolated as a pure culture.}}
What is defined media?
contains known quantities of all ingredients
What is undefined media (complex)?
contains complex ingredients in unknown proportions
Enriched media
contains the nutrients required to support the growth of a wide variety of organisms
Selective media
used for growth of only selected microorganisms
Differential media:
used to differentiate one microorganism type from another growing on the same medium.
Reducing media
used for growth of obligate anaerobes
Single-enzyme tests provide {{c1::presumptive}} identification.

What does a catalase test reveal? 
What are examples of catalase + and catalase - organisms?

A catalase test differnetiates between gram + bacteria that contain the enzyme catalase. If the organism is catalase positive it will rapidly produce bubbles when exposed to H2O2. H2O2 will be converted to H2O + O2 by catalase. 

Catalase + organsim: Staphylococci 
Catalase - organism: Streptococci and Enterococci
What is an oxidase test?
A single enzyme test that differentiates between gram negative bacteria. A dark oxidized product results from cytochrome c oxidase activity (a positive fro this test).
What is a coagulase test?
A coagulase test is a single enzyme test that is used to differentiate staphylococcus aureus (coagulase positive) from other staphylococci (coagulase negative).
What is a urease test? What color will the PH indicator turn if the organism contains urease?

A urease test helps to identigy species that contain the enzyme urease. Since urease hydrolyzes urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide, the alkalinity can be testested with PH indicators to determine the presence of urease. The PH indicator will turn dark  if the organism contains urease because more NH3 is being produced and thus the alkalinity is higher.
What is a metabolic pathway test?
A metabolic pathway test measures the presence of metabolic pathways in a bacterial isolate.

Initiation of infectious disease

Most of the cases by microbes {{c3::!colonizing}} 
{{c1::Skin::surface}}
{{c2::Mucous membrane::surface}}

Exception
Direct introduction into
{{c4::Bloodstream}}
{{c5::Internal organs}}

Initiation of infectious disease

Colonization of microbes
Possible scenarios:
{{c1::Elimination}} of the microbe, host {{c1::not effected}}
Host develops {{c2::Infectious disease::physiological condition}}
Host becomes {{c3::carrier}} (transient or prolonged)

Infectious disease

Definition:
When foreign microorganisms
Cause {{c1::tissue damage}}
Impair {{c2::body function}}

Classification
  • Bacteria: {{c1::Pro}}karyotes
  • Fungi: {{c2::Eu}}karyotes
  • Protozoa: {{c3::Eu}}karyotes
  • Helminths: {{c4::Eu}}karyotes
  • Human: {{c5::Eu}}karyotes

Prokaryotic Pathogens

Typical bacteria
Common shapes:
  • {{c1::Bacillus}}
  • {{c2::Coccus}}
  • {{c3::Spirillus}}
Exception: "{{c4::Pleomorphic}}" (No {{c5::distinct shape}})

Prokaryotic Pathogens

Typical 
Bacteria cell wall:
  • Gram {{c1::-}} ({{c3::thick::thick/thin}} cell wall):  
  • Gram {{c2::+}} ({{c4::thin::thick/thin}} cell wall):

Fungi

Characteristics
  • {{c1::Eu}}karyotic
  • {{c2::Uni- or multi}}cellular
  • Reproduction: {{c3::asexual, sexaul, or both::sexual/asexual}}
  • Produces {{c4::spores}} for {{c5::dispersal}} and survival in unfavorable conditions
  • Photosynthesis: {{c6::not}}
  • {{c7::!Saprophytic}}: Feed on {{c8::!dead or decaying}} matter
  • Pathogenic disease range from {{c9::skin infection to systemic infections::extent}}

Fungi

Medically important fungi:

Disease: Causal agent: affected sites
  • Candidiasis: {{c1::Candida Albicans}} (Affected area/s: {{c6::Vagina, mouth}})
  • Cryptococcosis: {{c2::Cryptococcus neoformans}} (Affected area/s: {{c7::Lungs, Meninges, Wound/skins}})
  • Histoplasmosis: {{c3::Histoplasma Capsulatum}} (Affected area/s: {{c8::lungs}})
  • Aspergillosis: {{c4::Aspergillus niger}} (Affected area/s: {{c9::Lungs}})
  • Blastomycosis: {{c5::Blastomyces dermatitidis}}  (Affected area/s: {{c10::lungs}})

Protozoa

Characteristics

  • {{c1::Eu}}karyotic
  • {{c2::Uni::#}}cellular
  • Photosynthesis: {{c3::not}}
  • Live style: {{c4::Free living and parasitic}}
  • {{c5::Intra- and extra::intra/extra}}cellular parasites in blood, urogenital regions, or intestine

Protozoa

Medically important species
  • Giardia lamblia: {{c1::Intestine}}
  • Trichomoniasis vaginalis: {{c2::Urogenital}}
  • Trypoanosoma sp.: {{c3::Blood and tissues}}
  • Leishmania sp.: {{c4::Blood and tissues}}
Helminths: "{{c1::Worms::layman term}}"

Helminths: 

Characteristics
  • Layman term: "{{c1::Worms}}"
  • {{c2::Eu}}karyotic
  • {{c3::Multi::#}}cellular
  • Livestyle: {{c4::parasitic}}

Helminths: 

divided into following groups:
  • {{c1::Nematodes}}: {{c4::Roundworms}}
  • {{c2::Cestodes}}: {{c5::Tapeworms}}
  • {{c3::Trematodes}}: {{c6::Flukes}}

Helminths: 

divided into following groups:
  • {{c1::Nematodes}}: Roundworms

{{c1::!Enterobiasis}}

Most common {{c3::!helminth}} infection in US
  • Symptoms: {{c2::Anal itching}}

Ingestion of {{c3::<cz_hide>!</cz_hide>undercooked pork}} poses significant risk of {{c1::<cz_hide>!</cz_hide>Trichinella spiralis}} (belonging to group {{c2::<cloze2_w class='cz-2'></cloze2_w><cloze2 class='cz-2'>nematodes</cloze2>}}) infection.

Location: {{c3::Anus}}

Viruses 

Characteristic

"{{c1::Obligate::necessity}} {{c2::Intracellular::location}} {{c3::parasites::Life style}}"

Viruses 

Characteristics
  • Replication: {{c1::host cell}} necessary
  • Cellular structure: {{c2::no::y/n}}
  • Nucleic acid: {{c3::DNA or R::DNA/RNA}}NA
  • Arrangement: Nucleic acid surrounded by {{c4::protein coat}}
  • Some coated with membrane derived from {{c5::host cell membrane}}
Virus Particle: "{{c6::<cloze2_w class='cz-6'></cloze2_w><cloze2 class='cz-6'>Virion</cloze2>}}"

{{c1::Pathogenicity}} of a microbe depends on its success in completing some or all of these stages
{{c1::Virulence factors}} are those characteristics of a bacterium that enhance its pathogenicity

Virulence can be quantified by:
{{c1::1. Infectious Dose ( ID 50 ):}} how many organisms are required to cause disease in 50%
    of those exposed
{{c2::2. Lethal Dose ( LD 50 ):}} how many organisms kill 50% of test animals
(T/F) - The number of organisms required to cause disease varies greatly among pathogenic bacteria.
T

Virulence factors include: 
1.{{c1::Capsule}}

2.{{c2::Surface adhesion molecule}}

3.{{c3::Bacterial enzymes}} such as collagenase and hyaluronidase

4.{{c4::Iron binding proteins}} to obtain iron for growth

5.Bacterial {{c5::toxins}}

Virulence factors include:
1.{{c1::Capsule}} - outer protection

2.{{c2::Surface adhesion molecule}} - "stickiness"

3.{{c3::Bacterial enzymes}} - such as collagenase and hyaluronidase

4.{{c4::Iron binding proteins}} - to obtain iron for growth

5.Bacterial {{c5::toxins}}
{{c2::Exotoxins}} are proteins {{c1::secreted}} by both gram positive and gram negative bacteria.
Endotoxins are not secreted but can be released by {{c1::bacterial lysis.}} They are components of the outer membrane in {{c2::gram negative bacteria. }}
{{c1::Exotoxins}} are heat labile and generally more toxic. {{c2::Endotoxins}} are heat stable.
The pathogenesis of many bacterial infections is caused by the {{c1::host response}} rather than by bacterial factors
Tissue damage in host-mediated pathogenesis is caused by various {{c1::cytokines}} released from host cells.

Viral infections can lead to: 

{{c1::Cell death}}: A cell can be directly killed by the virus
 - Mostly due to inhibition of protein and nucleic acid synthesis

{{c2::Transformation}}: Some viruses can transform normal cells into malignant cells
-Due to integration of viral DNA into host DNA

{{c3::Cell fusion}}: Infection of cells with certain viruses causes the cells to fuse, producing giant, multinucleate cells
  - Due to virus induced changes in host cell membrane

{{c4::Cytopathic effect}}: Any visible change in appearance of an infected cell e.g. rounding, patches of stainable viral proteins inside the cell, and cell disintegration
The human body is continuously inhabited by many different microbes. These microbes are termed normal microbiota" (formerly 'normal flora') or {{c1::commensals}}

Under normal circumstances in a healthy individual, they are harmless and may even be beneficial

A healthy newborn enters the world in essentially sterile condition, but, after birth, it rapidly acquires normal microbiota from food and the environment, including from other humans
The human {{c1::microbiome}} is the total number and diversity of microbes in and on the human body

It is difficult to define the human microbiome because it varies from person to person due to some factors like:

1) {{c1::Physiologic differences}}
2) {{c1::Diet}}
3) {{c1::Age}}
4) {{c1::Geographic habitat}}

The most common sites of the body inhabited by normal microbiota are those in contact or in communication with the outside world such as:

1) {{c1::Skin}}
2) {{c1::Eye}}
3) {{c1::Mouth}} and {{c1::nose}}
4) {{c1::Intestinal tract}}
5) {{c1::Urogenital tract}}
Staphylococcus epidermidis, Staphylococcus aureus, and Propionibacterium acnes are normal microbiota species typically found on the {{c1::skin}}.

{{c1::Staphylococcus epidermidis}}

Makes up 90% of skin aerobes
Reside in the outer layers of the skin
Can colonize on plastic catheters and medical devices that penetrate the skin

Gram + cocci

{{c1::Staphylococcus aureus}}

A type of microbiota that tends to cause skin infections

Gram + cocci

{{c1::Propionibacterium acnes}}

Generally anerobic
Reside in deeper layers of the skin, hair follicles, sweat glands and sebaceous glands
Associated with acne

Gram + bacilli

Microbiota that are found on the eye are:

1.{{c1::Staphylococcus epidermidis}}
2.{{c2::Staphylococcus aureus}}
3.{{c3::Corynebacterium species}}
4.{{c4::Streptococcus pneumoniae}}
Other organisms that normally inhabit the skin also occur but at a lower frequency

The two main microbiota that exist in the mouth and nose are:

1) {{c1::Streptococcus mutans}}
2) {{c1::Streptococcus pneumoniae}}

{{c3::Streptococcus mutans}}

  - colonize the {{c1::teeth}} and {{c1::gingival tissue}}
  - promotes the formation of {{c4::plaque}}
  - can enter the bloodstream following dental surgery and colonize damaged or prosthetic {{c2::heart valves}}, leading to potentially fatal infective endocarditis

{{c1::Streptococcus pneumoniae}}

  - colonize the {{c2::respiratory tracts}}, {{c2::sinuses}}, and {{c2::nasal cavity}}
  - can especially affect the elderly and immunocompromised
The density of microbes in the stomach is relatively {{c1::low::high or low?}}
This is due to the low pH
The microbiota density increases along the {{c1::alimentary}} canal
The microbiota in the {{c1::gut}} has the largest numbers of bacteria and the greatest number of species compared to other areas of the body.
Some 20% of the fecal mass consists of many different species of bacteria, <u>> 90% of which are </u>{{c1::anaerobes::aerobes or anerobes?}}
{{c1::Bacteroides}} species constitute a significant percentage of the {{c2::large intestine}}
ie. Bacteriodes fragilis - causes intra-abdominal abcesses
{{c1::Lactobacillus}} species maintains the low pH of the vagina
Lactobacillus species maintains the {{c1::low pH of the vagina}}
{{c1::Candida albicans}} is a yeast-like fungus that can overgrow in the absence of normal vaginal flora.

Some of the beneficial functions of normal microbiota are:

1) {{c1::competition}} with pathogenic microbes for nutrients and receptor sites
2) the production of {{c2::antimicrobial substances}}
3) act as a stimulus for {{c3::the development of the immune system}}
4) gut bacteria provides {{c4::nutrients}} that otherwise the body cannot produce
{{c1::E. coli}} is a gut microbiota that provides us with {{c2::vitamin K}}

Some harmful effects of microbiota occur:

1) When normal microbiota organisms are displaced from their normal site to an abnormal site. ({{c1::Opportunistic infection}})
2) When normal microbiota populations {{c2::diminish}} and potential pathogens gain a competitive advantage
3) When ingested food substances are converted to {{c3::carcinogenic derivatives}} by bacteria in the colon
4) When normal microbiota overgrow and become {{c4::pathogenic}} in immunocompromised individuals
